qas.question: What type of engines became popular for power generation after piston steam engines?

context: <a0_2><a1_0><a1_3><b5_0>Reciprocating piston<b5_0/><a1_0/><a0_2/> type<a1_3/> steam engines remained the dominant source of power until the early 20th century, when advances in the design of <a1_2><a2_2>electric motors<a2_2/> and <a0_1><a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b7_0>internal combustion<b7_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/><a1_2/> engines<a0_1/> gradually resulted in the replacement of reciprocating (piston) steam engines in commercial usage, and the ascendancy of <a0_0><a0_3><a1_1><b4_0>steam turbines<b4_0/><a1_1/><a0_3/><a0_0/> in power generation. Considering that the great majority of worldwide electric generation is produced by <a2_0><a2_1><a2_3><b6_0>turbine<b6_0/><a2_0/> type<a2_3/><a2_1/> steam engines, the "<b8_0>steam age<b8_0/>" is continuing with energy levels far beyond those of the turn of the 19th century.
